p: The model is composed of two phases: (i) the phase of reaction, defined by the epidemioloigcal model (see the section Materials and Methods for details and Fig. 1(b) for a schematic overview), where disease transmission takes place in each grid cell; (ii) the phase of diffusion where agents are moved from one grid cell to another according to the mobility model under consideration: the mobility flows aggregated at census district level for the different mobility models are reported in Fig. 2. Each day consists of two reaction phases, corresponding to day and night, and two diffusion phases, corresponding to people’s morning and evening commute.
